name: Kepler-208
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-208 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-208 is a star with 1.7 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.31 times its radius. It is located 2586.45 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-208 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-208 b

Kepler-208 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 4.23 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-208.

The mass of Kepler-208 b is 3.09 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-208 b is 1.63 that of Earth. At 3.09 Earth masses, Kepler-208 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-208 c

Kepler-208 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 7.47 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-208.

The mass of Kepler-208 c is 2.12 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-208 c is 1.39 that of Earth. At 2.12 Earth masses, Kepler-208 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-208 d

Kepler-208 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 11.13 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-208.

The mass of Kepler-208 d is 1.49 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-208 d is 1.2 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-208 d is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-208 e

Kepler-208 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.13 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 16.26 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-208.

The mass of Kepler-208 e is 2.46 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-208 e is 1.48 that of Earth. At 2.46 Earth masses, Kepler-208 e is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-208, which contains 4 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
